text: My hands also will I lift up unto thy commandments, which I have loved; and I will meditate in thy statutes.
text_kjv: My hands also will I lift up unto thy commandments, which I have loved; and I will meditate in thy statutes.
text_niv: I lift up my hands to your commands, which I love,and I meditate on your decrees.
text_esv: I will lift up my hands toward your commandments, which I love, and I will meditate on your statutes.
text_nlt: I honor and love your commands.I meditate on your decrees.
text_msg: relishing every fragment of your counsel.
text_nasb: And I shall lift up my hands to Your commandments, Which I love; And I will meditate on Your statutes. Zayin.
context: Psalm 119, the longest chapter in the Bible, is an acrostic poem, with each section (eight verses) devoted to a letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This structure reflects the comprehensive nature of God's law and its pervasive influence on every aspect of life. The author, traditionally believed to be David but possibly another devout Israelite leader or scribe, expresses deep love and reverence for God's word (Torah). In ancient Israelite society, the Torah was not merely a legal code but a guide for righteous living, a covenantal agreement with Yahweh, and a source of wisdom. 'Commandments' (mitzvot) were understood as divine instructions meant to lead individuals and the nation into a closer relationship with God. 'Statutes' (chukkim) were a subset of God's law often dealing with rituals or specific decrees, and were often understood as uniquely and directly from God, less reasoned than 'judgments' or 'ordinances'. The lifting of hands was a common posture of prayer and reverence, symbolizing submission, supplication, and a desire to receive God's blessing and guidance. Meditation, in this context, wasn't just passive reflection, but an active and intentional engagement with the divine text, internalizing its principles and applying them to daily life. The Psalmist lived in a world where written copies of the Torah were scarce, requiring deep memorization and constant recitation, making the 'meditation' aspect even more vital.
meaning: This verse encapsulates the Psalmist's devotion to God's law. The phrase 'My hands also will I lift up unto thy commandments' is both literal and symbolic. Literally, it signifies a physical act of worship and surrender, acknowledging God's authority and seeking His grace. Symbolically, 'lifting up hands' represents a wholehearted embrace of God's commandments, a commitment to living according to His will. The act itself is a prayer of dedication, a visible declaration of allegiance. The Psalmist isn't merely obeying God out of duty or fear, but out of love. 'Which I have loved' underscores the emotional and relational aspect of the Psalmist's faith. He doesn't see God's commandments as burdensome restrictions, but as expressions of God's love and wisdom, designed for his own good. This love transforms obedience from a chore into a joyous pursuit. 'And I will meditate in thy statutes' emphasizes the intellectual and spiritual engagement with God's word. 'Meditation' isn't just about reading or hearing the law; it's about internalizing it, reflecting on its meaning, and allowing it to shape one's thoughts, attitudes, and actions. This active reflection leads to deeper understanding and application of God's will. The coupling of physical action (lifting hands) with mental and spiritual activity (meditation) highlights the holistic nature of the Psalmist's devotion, demonstrating that true worship involves the entire being – body, soul, and mind.
application: In our modern lives, this verse presents a powerful model for engaging with God's Word. 'Lifting up hands' can symbolize our deliberate choice to surrender our will to God's and commit to following His teachings. Practically, this could mean making conscious decisions throughout the day that align with biblical principles – choosing honesty over deception, kindness over rudeness, forgiveness over resentment. It could also manifest in actively seeking opportunities to serve others and contribute to the greater good, motivated by our love for God. The phrase 'which I have loved' calls us to examine our own hearts and motivations. Do we see God's commands as restrictive or as a path to freedom and fulfillment? Cultivating a love for God's Word requires intentionality. We can start by regularly reading and studying the Bible, seeking to understand its historical context and practical implications. We can also engage in prayer and reflection, asking God to open our eyes to the truth and to empower us to live according to His will. 'I will meditate in thy statutes' urges us to move beyond superficial reading and delve deeper into the meaning of Scripture. This involves pondering, questioning, and applying biblical principles to our everyday lives. Consider journaling your thoughts and reflections as you read. Discuss the scripture with trusted friends or mentors. We can also use various resources like commentaries, Bible dictionaries, and study guides to gain a deeper understanding of the text. Digital tools make this meditation possible anywhere. Ultimately, the goal is not just to accumulate knowledge but to transform our hearts and minds, allowing God's Word to shape our character and guide our actions. In a world filled with distractions and competing voices, this verse reminds us of the importance of prioritizing God's Word and allowing it to be the foundation of our lives.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I lift up my hands to You, acknowledging Your sovereignty and Your boundless love. I confess that sometimes Your commandments feel challenging, but I desire to love them as the Psalmist did. Help me to see them not as restrictions, but as pathways to true freedom and joy. Grant me a heart that delights in Your Word, and a mind that is able to meditate on Your statutes day and night. Open my eyes to understand the depth of Your wisdom and empower me to live according to Your will. Fill me with Your Spirit, that I may walk in obedience and reflect Your love to the world. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: While physically lifting hands is still practiced in worship, it also represents a heart posture of surrender, openness to God, and a willingness to receive His guidance. It signifies a conscious choice to dedicate ourselves to God's will.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean to 'lift up hands' in a modern context?

faqs.answer: Start with small increments of time. Even 5-10 minutes of focused reflection on a single verse can be powerful. Use technology to your advantage by listening to scripture or devotionals during your commute or breaks.
faqs.question: Q2: How can I practically 'meditate' on God's statutes when I'm busy?

faqs.question: Q3: What is the difference between 'commandments' and 'statutes'?

faqs.answer: Pray for a love for God's word. Start by focusing on the positive aspects of obedience, the blessings and benefits it brings. Remember that following God is a way of expressing your love for Him.
faqs.question: Q4: How do I cultivate a genuine love for God's commandments?

faqs.answer: Love motivates us to obey joyfully, while meditation helps us understand and apply God's Word effectively. Both are essential for a deep and transformative relationship with God.
